lambda-calculus-0.1.0.0
  • Source

Safe HaskellSafe-Inferred
LanguageHaskell2010

LambdaAST

Description

This module defines the representation of lambda calculus expressions, including support for distinguishing free and bound variables, monadic substitution, and pretty-printing using the prettyprinter library.

Synopsis
  • data Variable a
    • = Bound
    • | Free a
  • data Lambda var
    • = Var var
    • | App (Lambda var) (Lambda var)
    • | LamAbs String (Lambda (Variable var))
  • lam :: String -> Lambda String -> Lambda String
  • prettyLambda :: (a -> Doc ann) -> Lambda a -> Doc ann
  • renderLambda :: Lambda String -> String

Documentation

data Variable a Source #

A variable in a lambda expression, either bound or free.

Bound represents a variable that is bound by a lambda abstraction. 'Free a' represents a free variable identified by some name or value of type a.

Constructors

Bound 
Free a

Applicative instance for Variable.

Allows the use of * to apply functions inside Free, propagating Bound.

data Lambda var Source #

The abstract syntax tree for lambda calculus terms.

Parameterized by the type of variables (e.g., String or 'Variable a').

Constructors:

  • Var — A variable, either bound or free.
  • App — Function application: (f x)
  • LamAbs — Lambda abstraction: λx. body

In LamAbs, the bound variable is named (for pretty-printing), but the body uses 'Variable var' to distinguish bound from free variables.

Constructors

Var var 
App (Lambda var) (Lambda var) 
LamAbs String (Lambda (Variable var))

Monad Lambda Source #

Monad instance for Lambda.

This is the heart of substitution: - 'Var a' is substituted by applying the function. - App and LamAbs are recursively traversed. - For LamAbs, the body is mapped with 'mapM f', because it contains nested 'Variable var' terms.

lam :: String -> Lambda String -> Lambda String Source #

Smart constructor for lambda abstractions.

Takes a variable name and a body term with plain String variables, and returns a Lambda expression where the named variable is replaced with Bound inside the body, and all other variables become Free.

This is what transforms a 'Lambda String' into a scoped 'Lambda (Variable String)'.

prettyLambda :: (a -> Doc ann) -> Lambda a -> Doc ann Source #

Pretty-prints a lambda expression using a user-supplied printer for variables.

Free variables are printed via the given function p :: a -> Doc ann. Bound variables are printed by the variable name captured in the nearest LamAbs.

renderLambda :: Lambda String -> String Source #

Renders a lambda expression as a human-readable string using prettyLambda.

This is the default printer that uses String variables.
